articles.headline: Sedition Sentence for Oath Keepers Leader Marks Moment of Accountability
articles.snippet: The 18 years in prison given to Stewart Rhodes for a rarely charged crime underscored the lengths to which the Justice Department and the courts have gone in addressing the assault on the Capitol.
articles.abstract: The 18 years in prison given to Stewart Rhodes for a rarely charged crime underscored the lengths to which the Justice Department and the courts have gone in addressing the assault on the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few hours after Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia, was sentenced on Thursday to 18 years in prison for his role in a seditious conspiracy to instigate the pro-Trump violence of Jan. 6, Matthew M. Graves, the federal prosecutor who has overseen the government’s investigation of the Capitol attack, released a statement with a fact that underscored the landmark nature of the moment.

articles.headline: How Fighting for Conservative Causes Has Helped Ken Paxton Survive Legal Woes
articles.snippet: With the Texas House set to vote on his impeachment, Mr. Paxton is counting on political support that he’s amassed as a Republican legal firebrand.
articles.abstract: With the Texas House set to vote on his impeachment, Mr. Paxton is counting on political support that he’s amassed as a Republican legal firebrand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton’s impeachment proceedings.

articles.headline: Has ‘Gig Work’ Become a Dirty Word?
articles.snippet: If work for companies like Uber and Lyft once carried some appeal for offering flexibility, the kind of labor it has come to represent is now used by some as shorthand for a raw deal.
articles.abstract: If work for companies like Uber and Lyft once carried some appeal for offering flexibility, the kind of labor it has come to represent is now used by some as shorthand for a raw deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: When more than 11,000 film and television writers in the Writers Guild of America union went on strike this month, they called out deteriorating working conditions, criticized unfair pay and said they worried about losing their jobs to artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: Missteps and Miscalculations: Inside Fox’s Legal and Business Debacle
articles.snippet: Fox’s handling of the defamation suit brought by Dominion Voting Systems, which settled for $787.5 million, left many unanswered questions.
articles.abstract: Fox’s handling of the defamation suit brought by Dominion Voting Systems, which settled for $787.5 million, left many unanswered questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 2021, the Fox Corporation board of directors gathered on the company’s movie studio lot in Los Angeles. Among the topics on the agenda: Dominion Voting Systems’ $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit against its cable news network, Fox News.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Michael S. Schmidt and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Reparations Are a Financial Quandary. For Democrats, They’re a Political One, Too.
articles.snippet: Republicans have criticized recent estimates of what Black Americans are owed in reparations. But for Democrats, they pose deeper problems for a party eager to retain the allegiance of Black voters.
articles.abstract: Republicans have criticized recent estimates of what Black Americans are owed in reparations. But for Democrats, they pose deeper problems for a party eager to retain the allegiance of Black voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: What should Americans pay for the legacy of slavery and a century of Jim Crow segregation?
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel, Maya King, Kurtis Lee and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: Barely Noting War in Public, Putin Acts Like Time Is on His Side
articles.snippet: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia looks like a commander in absentia, treating the war in Ukraine as unfortunate but distant. His options have narrowed, but he is still betting on outlasting his foes.
articles.abstract: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia looks like a commander in absentia, treating the war in Ukraine as unfortunate but distant. His options have narrowed, but he is still betting on outlasting his foes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pro-Ukrainian fighters stormed across the border into southwestern Russia this past week, prompting two days of the heaviest fighting on Russian territory in 15 months of war. Yet President Vladimir V. Putin, in public, ignored the matter entirely.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Paul Sonne

articles.headline: Ken Paxton Is Temporarily Suspended After Texas House Vote
articles.snippet: The state attorney general and conservative star faces a trial in the Senate.
articles.abstract: The state attorney general and conservative star faces a trial in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in the Texas House voted on Saturday to impeach Ken Paxton, the state’s Republican attorney general, temporarily removing him from office over charges that he had used his elected position to benefit himself and a campaign donor.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman, James Dobbins and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: White House and G.O.P. Strike Debt Limit Deal to Avert Default
articles.snippet: With the government on track to reach its borrowing limit within days, negotiators sealed an agreement to raise the debt ceiling for two years while cutting and capping certain federal programs.
articles.abstract: With the government on track to reach its borrowing limit within days, negotiators sealed an agreement to raise the debt ceiling for two years while cutting and capping certain federal programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy on Saturday reached an agreement in principle to lift the debt limit for two years while cutting and capping some government spending over the same period, a breakthrough after a marathon set of crisis talks that has brought the nation within days of its first default in history.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: A Russian Deserter’s Flight to Norway Presents a Fraught Dilemma for His Host
articles.snippet: Andrei Medvedev fought with Russia’s Wagner mercenaries in Ukraine, then requested asylum in Norway. The authorities there must now weigh his plea against solidarity with Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Andrei Medvedev fought with Russia’s Wagner mercenaries in Ukraine, then requested asylum in Norway. The authorities there must now weigh his plea against solidarity with Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sipping a $12 beer in one of the world’s wealthiest capitals, Andrei Medvedev reflected on the question hanging over him since he left the battlefields of Ukraine: Is he a hero or a war criminal?
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell

articles.headline: Meet the New Mayor: How a Refugee Won Over a Conservative German Town
articles.snippet: The election of Ryyan Alshebl, a young man who fled Syria, offers surprising lessons for a Germany wrestling with its multicultural identity after an influx of refugees in 2015.
articles.abstract: The election of Ryyan Alshebl, a young man who fled Syria, offers surprising lessons for a Germany wrestling with its multicultural identity after an influx of refugees in 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: The beer was flowing, the bratwurst were sizzling and the brass band at the village May Day festival led the crowd in ever tipsier renditions of the local drinking song.

articles.headline: In Pursuit of Consensus, Did Biden Find the Reasonable Middle or Give Away Too Much?
articles.snippet: The deal to raise the debt ceiling bolsters President Biden’s argument that he is committed to bipartisanship, but it comes at the cost of rankling many in his own party.
articles.abstract: The deal to raise the debt ceiling bolsters President Biden’s argument that he is committed to bipartisanship, but it comes at the cost of rankling many in his own party.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of tense wrangling between the White House and House Republicans, the fiscal deal reached on Saturday to raise the debt ceiling while constraining federal spending bolsters President Biden’s argument that he is the one figure who can still do bipartisanship in a profoundly partisan era.

articles.headline: Despite Inflation, Earthquakes and Tough Race, Erdogan Is Re-elected
articles.snippet: Recep Tayyip Erdogan has given few indications that he intends to change course at home, where he faces a looming economic crisis, or in foreign policy, where he has vexed Western allies.
articles.abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan has given few indications that he intends to change course at home, where he faces a looming economic crisis, or in foreign policy, where he has vexed Western allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan beat back the greatest political challenge of his career on Sunday, securing victory in a presidential runoff that granted five more years to a mercurial leader who has vexed his Western allies while tightening his grip on the Turkish state.

articles.headline: With Watchful Eyes, a Nationwide Network Tracks Antisemitic Threats
articles.snippet: The mass shooting at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh led to arguably the most ambitious effort ever undertaken to protect Jewish institutions in America.
articles.abstract: The mass shooting at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh led to arguably the most ambitious effort ever undertaken to protect Jewish institutions in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a dimly lit conference room on an upper floor of a Chicago mid-rise, an intricately detailed snapshot of American peril is being taken, minute by unsettling minute.

articles.headline: Cathay Pacific Fights to Emerge From the Long Shadow of Covid
articles.snippet: Pandemic lockdowns, on the heels of the turmoil of pro-democracy protests, hurt an airline that relied on Hong Kong as a vibrant gateway to Asia.
articles.abstract: Pandemic lockdowns, on the heels of the turmoil of pro-democracy protests, hurt an airline that relied on Hong Kong as a vibrant gateway to Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few major airlines in the world were hit by the Covid pandemic as hard as Cathay Pacific, the flagship carrier of Hong Kong, or have labored so mightily to recover from it. Its business was decimated by some of the industry’s most expansive flight bans and quarantine requirements. And the pandemic wasn’t the start of Cathay’s troubles.

articles.headline: The Mystery of the Disappearing van Gogh
articles.snippet: After a painting by the Dutch artist sold at auction, a movie producer claimed to be the owner. It later vanished from sight, with a trail leading to Caribbean tax havens and a jailed Chinese billionaire.
articles.abstract: After a painting by the Dutch artist sold at auction, a movie producer claimed to be the owner. It later vanished from sight, with a trail leading to Caribbean tax havens and a jailed Chinese billionaire.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bidding for Lot 17 started at $23 million.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe, Isabelle Qian, Muyi Xiao and Vivian Wang

articles.headline: Why Spending Cuts Likely Won’t Shake the Economy
articles.snippet: With low unemployment and above-trend inflation, the economy is well positioned to absorb the modest budget cuts that President Biden and Republicans negotiated.
articles.abstract: With low unemployment and above-trend inflation, the economy is well positioned to absorb the modest budget cuts that President Biden and Republicans negotiated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the United States came perilously close to defaulting on its debt, a Democratic president and a Republican speaker of the House cut a deal to raise the nation’s borrowing limit and tightly restrain some federal spending growth for years to come. The deal averted default, but it hindered what was already a slow recovery from the Great Recession.

articles.headline: A Small Town’s Tragedy, Distorted by Trump’s Megaphone
articles.snippet: When a teen’s killing became a right-wing talking point, the rush to outrage obscured a more complicated story.
articles.abstract: When a teen’s killing became a right-wing talking point, the rush to outrage obscured a more complicated story.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were no known witnesses when Shannon Brandt and Cayler Ellingson got into an argument in the blurry hours after last call at Buck’s n Doe’s Bar & Grill in September. And no one but Mr. Brandt could say with certainty what led him to run over Mr. Ellingson with his Ford Explorer, crushing him to death in a gravel alley.
articles.byline: By Charles Homans and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: Will Erdogan’s Victory Soften Turkey’s Opposition to Sweden in NATO?
articles.snippet: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, re-elected as Turkey’s president, is expected to toughen up at home but seek better ties with Washington and ratify Swedish membership of the military alliance.
articles.abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, re-elected as Turkey’s president, is expected to toughen up at home but seek better ties with Washington and ratify Swedish membership of the military alliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, invoking themes of Turkish nationalism and counterterrorism, has been the main obstacle toward Sweden joining the NATO alliance after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: She Said Her Professor Sexually Harassed Her. His Wife Won Damages.
articles.snippet: A case involving a graduate student and her art history professor illustrates the tangled state of sexual power dynamics in Japan.
articles.abstract: A case involving a graduate student and her art history professor illustrates the tangled state of sexual power dynamics in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: The prominent art history professor and his student had finished dinner and were strolling along the river in Kyoto, Japan’s picturesque former capital, when they stopped at a bar.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
